chinese.question: 以下哪项的推理模式与上述论证中的推理模式最为相似？
chinese.label: MUL
choices: (A)史密斯医生是一位训练有素的心脏病专家，他说如果心脏移植手术是由一位技术高超的外科医生进行的话，病人可能会活下来。因此，由于病人没有在手术中存活下来，所以手术很可能没有正确进行。
(B)对有机化学相当了解的威利斯教授说，该样品可能不包含任何有机化合物。因此，该样本可能没有正确的标签，因为如果是这样的话，它就会含有有机化合物。
(C)我的邻居是一个有经验的家庭装修者，他说如果墙壁得到适当的修复，就不会有明显的损坏。因此，对墙的修复可能没有做好，因为人们仍然可以注意到损坏的地方。
(D)建筑商说，学校的屋顶几年内都不需要修理，除非它在暴风雨中被损坏。屋顶已经在漏水了。因此，由于没有大的风暴，建筑商可能是错的。
(E)Yanakita教授是这方面的专家，他说，如果测试进行得当，会发现土壤中的铅。因此，由于测试确实发现了土壤中的铅，所以测试可能是正确进行的。
chinese.background: 最近的音乐会可能没有得到适当的宣传。对音乐会业务颇有研究的威尔斯确信，除非宣传不力，否则音乐会一定会卖光。但音乐会并没有卖出去。

english.passage: The recent concert was probably not properly promoted. Wells, who is quite knowledgeable about the concert business, was certain that it would sell out unless it was poorly promoted. But the concert did not sell out.
english.question: The pattern of reasoning in which one of the following is most similar to that in the argument above?
options: (A)Dr. Smith, a well-trained cardiologist, said the patient would probably survive the heart transplant if it were performed by a highly skilled surgeon. Thus, since the patient did not survive the surgery, it probably was not properly performed.

(B)Professor Willis, who is quite knowledgeable about organic chemistry, said that the sample probably did not contain any organic compounds. So, the sample probably is not labeled correctly, for if it were, it would contain organic compounds.

(C)My neighbor, who is an experienced home renovator, said the damage to the wall would not be noticeable if it were properly repaired. Thus, the repair to the wall probably was not properly done, since one can still notice the damage.

(D)The builder said that the school's roof would not require repairs for years, unless it is damaged in a storm. The roof is already leaking. Thus, since there have been no major storms, the builder was probably wrong.

(E)Professor Yanakita, who is an expert on the subject, said that the tests would find lead in the soil if they were properly conducted. So, since the tests did find lead in the soil, they probably were properly conducted.
english.label: MUL
english.answer: (C)My neighbor, who is an experienced home renovator, said the damage to the wall would not be noticeable if it were properly repaired. Thus, the repair to the wall probably was not properly done, since one can still notice the damage.
choices: (A)Dr. Smith, a well-trained cardiologist, said the patient would probably survive the heart transplant if it were performed by a highly skilled surgeon. Thus, since the patient did not survive the surgery, it probably was not properly performed.

(B)Professor Willis, who is quite knowledgeable about organic chemistry, said that the sample probably did not contain any organic compounds. So, the sample probably is not labeled correctly, for if it were, it would contain organic compounds.

(C)My neighbor, who is an experienced home renovator, said the damage to the wall would not be noticeable if it were properly repaired. Thus, the repair to the wall probably was not properly done, since one can still notice the damage.

(D)The builder said that the school's roof would not require repairs for years, unless it is damaged in a storm. The roof is already leaking. Thus, since there have been no major storms, the builder was probably wrong.

(E)Professor Yanakita, who is an expert on the subject, said that the tests would find lead in the soil if they were properly conducted. So, since the tests did find lead in the soil, they probably were properly conducted.
english.background: The recent concert was probably not properly promoted. Wells, who is quite knowledgeable about the concert business, was certain that it would sell out unless it was poorly promoted. But the concert did not sell out.

chinese.question: 以下哪项，如果是真的，最能加强论点？
chinese.label: MUL
choices: (A)经常需要开车去新的目的地的人比很少需要开车去新的目的地的人更有可能使用卫星导航。
(B)车辆消耗的燃料越多，司机就越有动力去寻找到达目的地的最短路线。
(C)不经常需要开车到不熟悉的地方的司机更有可能在出发前仔细计划他们的路线。
(D)拥有卫星导航仪的司机通常更愿意使用他们习惯的路线而不是按照卫星导航仪给出的方向行驶到他们习惯的目的地。
(E)根据需要得到指示的司机不太可能突然改变路线或做出其他危险的动作。
chinese.background: 汽车的卫星导航系统（satnavs），在驾驶过程中由电脑语音报出方向，可以节省燃料并促进安全。研究表明，当被分配到新的目的地时，使用卫星导航系统的司机比使用纸质地图的司机平均每次行驶的里程数少7%。更少的行驶里程意味着，平均来说，消耗的燃料更少。而且，使用卫星导航系统的司机开车更小心，因为他们不会把眼睛从路上移开来查看纸质地图。

english.passage: Satellite navigation systems (satnavs) for cars, in which computer voices announce directions as you drive, save fuel and promote safety. Studies show that, when assigned to novel destinations, drivers using satnavs took, on average, 7 percent fewer miles per journey than drivers using paper maps. Fewer miles driven means, on average, less fuel consumed. Also, the drivers who used satnavs drove more carefully in that they were not taking their eyes off the road to check paper maps.
english.question: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?
options: (A)People who are often required to drive to novel destinations are more likely to use satnavs than people who are rarely required to drive to novel destinations.
(B)The more fuel a vehicle consumes, the more motivation a driver has to find the shortest route to his or her destination.
(C)Drivers who do not routinely need to drive to an unfamiliar location are more likely to plan out their route carefully prior to departure.
(D)Drivers who own satnavs usually prefer to drive to their accustomed destinations by using their customary routes rather than by following the directions given by the satnavs.
(E)Drivers who are given directions as needed are less likely to change course suddenly or make other risky maneuvers.
english.label: MUL
english.answer: (E)Drivers who are given directions as needed are less likely to change course suddenly or make other risky maneuvers.
choices: (A)People who are often required to drive to novel destinations are more likely to use satnavs than people who are rarely required to drive to novel destinations.
(B)The more fuel a vehicle consumes, the more motivation a driver has to find the shortest route to his or her destination.
(C)Drivers who do not routinely need to drive to an unfamiliar location are more likely to plan out their route carefully prior to departure.
(D)Drivers who own satnavs usually prefer to drive to their accustomed destinations by using their customary routes rather than by following the directions given by the satnavs.
(E)Drivers who are given directions as needed are less likely to change course suddenly or make other risky maneuvers.
english.background: Satellite navigation systems (satnavs) for cars, in which computer voices announce directions as you drive, save fuel and promote safety. Studies show that, when assigned to novel destinations, drivers using satnavs took, on average, 7 percent fewer miles per journey than drivers using paper maps. Fewer miles driven means, on average, less fuel consumed. Also, the drivers who used satnavs drove more carefully in that they were not taking their eyes off the road to check paper maps.

chinese.question: 以下哪一项是论证所依赖的假设？
chinese.label: MUL
choices: (A)如果句子实际上是不间断的声音流，就不可能理解。
(B)不懂一种语言的人无法听到该语言的语音实际听起来的样子。
(C)人们对自己的语言听起来的注意程度比对不熟悉的语言听起来的注意程度低。
(D)有成就的非母语者不会把句子看作是声音的流。
(E)说母语的人对自己的语言的感知并不比不懂该语言的人的感知更准确。
chinese.background: 说母语的人把自己语言的句子看作是独立的词的序列。但这种感知是一种错觉。不懂当地语言的旅行者听到的是无法理解的、不间断的声音流，而不是有明显单词的句子，就说明了这一点。

english.passage: Native speakers perceive sentences of their own language as sequences of separate words. But this perception is an illusion. This is shown by the fact that travelers who do not know a local language hear an unintelligible, uninterrupted stream of sound, not sentences with distinct words.
english.question: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
options: (A)It is impossible to understand sentences if they are in fact uninterrupted streams of sound.
(B)Those who do not know a language cannot hear the way speech in that language actually sounds.
(C)People pay less close attention to the way their own language sounds than they do to the way an unfamiliar language sounds.
(D)Accomplished non-native speakers of a language do not perceive sentences as streams of sound.
(E)Native speakers' perceptions of their own language are not more accurate than are the perceptions of persons who do not know that language.
english.label: MUL
english.answer: (E)Native speakers' perceptions of their own language are not more accurate than are the perceptions of persons who do not know that language.
choices: (A)It is impossible to understand sentences if they are in fact uninterrupted streams of sound.
(B)Those who do not know a language cannot hear the way speech in that language actually sounds.
(C)People pay less close attention to the way their own language sounds than they do to the way an unfamiliar language sounds.
(D)Accomplished non-native speakers of a language do not perceive sentences as streams of sound.
(E)Native speakers' perceptions of their own language are not more accurate than are the perceptions of persons who do not know that language.
english.background: Native speakers perceive sentences of their own language as sequences of separate words. But this perception is an illusion. This is shown by the fact that travelers who do not know a local language hear an unintelligible, uninterrupted stream of sound, not sentences with distinct words.

chinese.question: 该科学记者的言论最有力地支持了以下哪一项？
chinese.label: MUL
choices: (A)任何大气中没有锂的天体都是质量小于太阳的恒星。
(B)任何大气中含有锂的天体都有一个核炉，该核炉未完全混合该天体的元素。
(C)大气中没有锂的天体都不是褐矮星。
(D)没有一个大气层中含有锂的天体的质量比太阳小。
(E)没有一个质量小于褐矮星的天体在其大气中含有锂。
chinese.background: 科学记者：褐矮星是质量比行星大但比恒星小的天体。它们根据其质量和大气层中是否存在锂来识别。至少和太阳一样大的恒星，其大气层中仍有锂，因为其内部核炉中的元素混合是不完全的。质量小于太阳的恒星没有锂，因为这种元素已经被完全混合到它们的核炉中并被消耗掉。褐矮星没有一个功能齐全的核炉，所以它的锂不能被消耗掉。

english.passage: Science journalist: Brown dwarfs are celestial objects with more mass than planets but less mass than stars. They are identified by their mass and whether or not lithium is present in their atmospheres. Stars at least as massive as the Sun have lithium remaining in their atmospheres because the mixing of elements in their internal nuclear furnaces is incomplete. Stars with less mass than the Sun have no lithium because the element has been fully mixed into their nuclear furnaces and consumed. A brown dwarf does not have a fully functional nuclear furnace and so its lithium cannot be consumed.
english.question: Which one of the following is most strongly supported by the science journalist's statements?
options: (A)Any celestial object without lithium in its atmosphere is a star with less mass than the Sun.
(B)Any celestial object with lithium in its atmosphere has a nuclear furnace that has incompletely mixed the object's elements.
(C)No celestial object that has no lithium in its atmosphere is a brown dwarf.
(D)No celestial object with lithium in its atmosphere has less mass than the Sun.
(E)No celestial object less massive than a brown dwarf has lithium in its atmosphere.
english.label: MUL
english.answer: (C)No celestial object that has no lithium in its atmosphere is a brown dwarf.
choices: (A)Any celestial object without lithium in its atmosphere is a star with less mass than the Sun.
(B)Any celestial object with lithium in its atmosphere has a nuclear furnace that has incompletely mixed the object's elements.
(C)No celestial object that has no lithium in its atmosphere is a brown dwarf.
(D)No celestial object with lithium in its atmosphere has less mass than the Sun.
(E)No celestial object less massive than a brown dwarf has lithium in its atmosphere.
english.background: Science journalist: Brown dwarfs are celestial objects with more mass than planets but less mass than stars. They are identified by their mass and whether or not lithium is present in their atmospheres. Stars at least as massive as the Sun have lithium remaining in their atmospheres because the mixing of elements in their internal nuclear furnaces is incomplete. Stars with less mass than the Sun have no lithium because the element has been fully mixed into their nuclear furnaces and consumed. A brown dwarf does not have a fully functional nuclear furnace and so its lithium cannot be consumed.

chinese.question: 以下哪一项如果是真的，会最严重地削弱上述论点？
chinese.label: MUL
choices: (A)因为警察局长认为卡尔是最有能力的侦探，所以她只给他分配最困难的案件，那些其他人未能解决的案件。
(B)在成为侦探之前，卡尔是一名社区警察，受到他巡逻的社区居民的高度尊重。
(C)卡尔所服务的警察队伍中的侦探得到了广泛的资源，包括使用一个大型计算机数据库，以帮助他们解决犯罪问题。
(D)卡尔以前在另一个城市的警察部门担任侦探，在他在那里度过的4年中，他只解决了30个犯罪中的一个。
(E)卡尔所服务的警察部门中的许多警官都是在过去5年内被雇用或晋升的。
chinese.background: 卡尔显然是一个不称职的侦探。在过去的3年中，他解决了分配给他的案件中较少的百分比--25件中只有1件--比警队中的其他侦探都要少。

english.passage: Carl is clearly an incompetent detective. He has solved a smaller percentage of the cases assigned to him in the last 3 years—only 1 out of 25—than any other detective on the police force.
english.question: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument above?
options: (A)Because the police chief regards Carl as the most capable detective, she assigns him only the most difficult cases, ones that others have failed to solve.
(B)Before he became a detective, Carl was a neighborhood police officer and was highly respected by the residents of the neighborhood he patrolled.
(C)Detectives on the police force on which Carl serves are provided with extensive resources, including the use of a large computer database, to help them solve crimes.
(D)Carl was previously a detective in a police department in another city, and in the 4 years he spent there, he solved only 1 out of 30 crimes.
(E)Many of the officers in the police department in which Carl serves were hired or promoted within the last 5 years.
english.label: MUL
english.answer: (A)Because the police chief regards Carl as the most capable detective, she assigns him only the most difficult cases, ones that others have failed to solve.
choices: (A)Because the police chief regards Carl as the most capable detective, she assigns him only the most difficult cases, ones that others have failed to solve.
(B)Before he became a detective, Carl was a neighborhood police officer and was highly respected by the residents of the neighborhood he patrolled.
(C)Detectives on the police force on which Carl serves are provided with extensive resources, including the use of a large computer database, to help them solve crimes.
(D)Carl was previously a detective in a police department in another city, and in the 4 years he spent there, he solved only 1 out of 30 crimes.
(E)Many of the officers in the police department in which Carl serves were hired or promoted within the last 5 years.
english.background: Carl is clearly an incompetent detective. He has solved a smaller percentage of the cases assigned to him in the last 3 years—only 1 out of 25—than any other detective on the police force.

chinese.question: 以下哪一项，如果是真的，最有助于解释治疗后一周的细菌浓度？
chinese.label: MUL
choices: (A)新的治疗方法需要几周的时间来进行。
(B)幼雏中沙门氏菌的水平一般开始时不高。
(C)大多数雏鸡在成年时对许多有害细菌产生抵抗力。
(D)未经处理的小鸡因沙门氏菌以外的细菌感染而患病的发生率比经处理的小鸡高。
(E)在经处理的小鸡中发现的细菌是非病毒性类型，其生长受到沙门氏菌的抑制。
chinese.background: 研究人员：沙门氏菌是导致食用家禽的人类患病的一个主要原因。接受新治疗的幼雏表现出的沙门氏菌感染率比未经治疗的幼雏低，尽管在治疗一周后，接受治疗的幼雏的各种细菌浓度比未经治疗的幼雏高。

english.passage: Researcher: Sal-monella bacteria are a major cause of illness in humans who consume poultry. Young chicks that underwent a new treatment exhibited a lower incidence of Salmonella infection than did untreated chicks, although one week after the treatment was administered the treated chicks had higher concentrations of a variety of bacteria than did untreated chicks.
english.question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to explain the concentrations of bacteria one week after the treatment?
options: (A)The new treatment takes several weeks to administer.
(B)Levels of Salmonella bacteria in young chicks are generally not high to begin with.
(C)Most chicks develop resistance to many harmful bacteria by the time they reach adulthood.
(D)The untreated chicks experienced a higher incidence of illness from infection by bacteria other than Salmonella than did treated chicks.
(E)The bacteria found in the treated chicks were nonvirulent types whose growth is inhibited by Salmonella bacteria.
english.label: MUL
english.answer: (E)The bacteria found in the treated chicks were nonvirulent types whose growth is inhibited by Salmonella bacteria.
choices: (A)The new treatment takes several weeks to administer.
(B)Levels of Salmonella bacteria in young chicks are generally not high to begin with.
(C)Most chicks develop resistance to many harmful bacteria by the time they reach adulthood.
(D)The untreated chicks experienced a higher incidence of illness from infection by bacteria other than Salmonella than did treated chicks.
(E)The bacteria found in the treated chicks were nonvirulent types whose growth is inhibited by Salmonella bacteria.
english.background: Researcher: Sal-monella bacteria are a major cause of illness in humans who consume poultry. Young chicks that underwent a new treatment exhibited a lower incidence of Salmonella infection than did untreated chicks, although one week after the treatment was administered the treated chicks had higher concentrations of a variety of bacteria than did untreated chicks.

chinese.question: 如果上面的陈述是真的，那么以下哪一项也一定是真的？
chinese.label: MUL
choices: (A)地球的地壳开始形成的时间不超过3亿年。
(B)地壳最早形成于现在的西澳大利亚地区。
(C)地壳的形成花了几十亿年的时间。
(D)微钻石是地壳最早形成的成分。
(E)所有自然发生的微钻石都是在地壳形成时形成的。
chinese.background: 在西澳大利亚工作的研究人员发现了目前已经确定的地球早期地壳的最古老的碎片：微钻石。这些微观晶体的直径只有50微米，形成于42亿年前。这一发现揭示了地壳形成所需的时间，因为这一日期仅比地球本身的形成晚3亿年。

english.passage: Researchers working in Western Australia have discovered the oldest fragments of the Earth's early crust that have yet been identified: microdiamonds. These microscopic crystals measure only 50 microns across and were formed 4.2 billion years ago. This discovery sheds light on how long it took for the Earth's crust to form, since this date is only 300 million years after the formation of the Earth itself.
english.question: If the statements above are true, which one of the following must also be true?
options: (A)The Earth's crust took no longer than 300 million years to start to form.
(B)The Earth's crust first formed in the area that is now Western Australia.
(C)The Earth's crust took billions of years to form.
(D)Microdiamonds were the first components of the Earth's crust to form.
(E)All naturally occurring microdiamonds were formed at the time the Earth's crust was being formed.
english.label: MUL
english.answer: (A)The Earth's crust took no longer than 300 million years to start to form.
choices: (A)The Earth's crust took no longer than 300 million years to start to form.
(B)The Earth's crust first formed in the area that is now Western Australia.
(C)The Earth's crust took billions of years to form.
(D)Microdiamonds were the first components of the Earth's crust to form.
(E)All naturally occurring microdiamonds were formed at the time the Earth's crust was being formed.
english.background: Researchers working in Western Australia have discovered the oldest fragments of the Earth's early crust that have yet been identified: microdiamonds. These microscopic crystals measure only 50 microns across and were formed 4.2 billion years ago. This discovery sheds light on how long it took for the Earth's crust to form, since this date is only 300 million years after the formation of the Earth itself.

chinese.question: 以下哪个论点中的错误推理模式与上述论点中的错误推理模式最为相似？
chinese.label: MUL
choices: (A)大多数药店出售化妆品。实际上每家药店都卖洗发水或牙膏，或者两者都卖。因此，如果有药店既卖化妆品又卖牙膏，那么也一定有一些药店既卖化妆品又卖洗发水。
(B)毫无疑问，大多数药店都卖化妆品，因为几乎所有的药店都卖洗发水或牙膏，或者都卖，有一些药店既卖化妆品又卖洗发水，还有一些药店既卖化妆品又卖牙膏。
(C)大多数药店出售化妆品。几乎所有的药店都卖洗发水或牙膏，或者两者都卖。因此，除非有一些药店既卖化妆品又卖牙膏，否则一定有一些药店既卖化妆品又卖洗发水。
(D)几乎所有卖洗发水的药店都卖牙膏。大多数药店都卖化妆品。因此，一定有一些药店既卖化妆品又卖牙膏，还有一些药店既卖化妆品又卖洗发水。
(E)几乎所有的药店都卖洗发水或牙膏，或者都卖。因此，既然大多数药店都卖化妆品，那么一定有一些药店既卖化妆品又卖牙膏，还有一些药店既卖化妆品又卖洗发水。
chinese.background: 大多数种类的土壤都含有粘土，而几乎每一种土壤都含有沙子或有机物，或两者都含有。因此，一定有一些土壤同时含有粘土和沙子，还有一些土壤同时含有粘土和有机物。

english.passage: Most kinds of soil contain clay, and virtually every kind of soil contains either sand or organic material, or both. Therefore, there must be some kinds of soil that contain both clay and sand and some that contain both clay and organic material.
english.question: The pattern of flawed reasoning in which one of the following arguments is most parallel to that in the argument above?
options: (A)Most pharmacies sell cosmetics. Vrrtually every pharmacy sells shampoo or toothpaste, or both. Therefore, if there are pharmacies that sell both cosmetics and toothpaste, there must also be some that sell both cosmetics and shampoo.

(B)Undoubtedly, most pharmacies sell cosmetics for almost all pharmacies sell either shampoo or toothpaste, or both, and there are some pharmacies that sell both cosmetics and shampoo and some that sell both cosmetics and toothpaste.

(C)Most pharmacies sell cosmetics. Nearly all pharmacies sell shampoo or toothpaste, or both. Therefore, unless there are some pharmacies that sell both cosmetics and toothpaste, there must be some that sell both cosmetics and shampoo.

(D)Virtually every pharmacy that sells shampoo also sells toothpaste. Most pharmacies sell cosmetics. Therefore, there must be some pharmacies that sell both cosmetics and toothpaste and some that sell both cosmetics and shampoo

(E)Nearly all pharmacies sell either shampoo or toothpaste, or both. Therefore, since most pharmacies sell cosmetics, there must be some pharmacies that sell both cosmetics and toothpaste and some that sell both cosmetics and shampoo.
english.label: MUL
english.answer: (E)Nearly all pharmacies sell either shampoo or toothpaste, or both. Therefore, since most pharmacies sell cosmetics, there must be some pharmacies that sell both cosmetics and toothpaste and some that sell both cosmetics and shampoo.
choices: (A)Most pharmacies sell cosmetics. Vrrtually every pharmacy sells shampoo or toothpaste, or both. Therefore, if there are pharmacies that sell both cosmetics and toothpaste, there must also be some that sell both cosmetics and shampoo.

(B)Undoubtedly, most pharmacies sell cosmetics for almost all pharmacies sell either shampoo or toothpaste, or both, and there are some pharmacies that sell both cosmetics and shampoo and some that sell both cosmetics and toothpaste.

(C)Most pharmacies sell cosmetics. Nearly all pharmacies sell shampoo or toothpaste, or both. Therefore, unless there are some pharmacies that sell both cosmetics and toothpaste, there must be some that sell both cosmetics and shampoo.

(D)Virtually every pharmacy that sells shampoo also sells toothpaste. Most pharmacies sell cosmetics. Therefore, there must be some pharmacies that sell both cosmetics and toothpaste and some that sell both cosmetics and shampoo

(E)Nearly all pharmacies sell either shampoo or toothpaste, or both. Therefore, since most pharmacies sell cosmetics, there must be some pharmacies that sell both cosmetics and toothpaste and some that sell both cosmetics and shampoo.
english.background: Most kinds of soil contain clay, and virtually every kind of soil contains either sand or organic material, or both. Therefore, there must be some kinds of soil that contain both clay and sand and some that contain both clay and organic material.

chinese.question: 以下哪项，如果是真的，最有助于解释为什么医生对一些癌症患者的建议与关于维生素C的一般建议不同？
chinese.label: MUL
choices: (A)某些种类的癌细胞吸收大量的维生素C，这干扰了许多癌症疗法杀死癌细胞的氧化机制。
(B)维生素C没有被证明可以减少人们患癌症的风险，即使是在一些医生推荐的非常高的剂量水平。
(C)易受某些类型癌症疗法影响的癌细胞不可能受到维生素C的影响。
(D)癌症患者在接受治疗时的整体健康状况越好，他们就越有可能经历完全康复。
(E)某些不利于患者整体健康的癌症疗法的副作用，不会受到维生素C的影响。
chinese.background: 医学专栏作家：一些医生建议服用维生素C来帮助维持整体健康，因为维生素C是一种抗氧化剂，这种物质可以保护身体不受某些类型的氧粒子的影响，这些氧粒子会引发疾病。患有各种疾病的人被鼓励服用维生素C，以防范出现其他健康问题。然而，现在医生不鼓励一些癌症患者服用维生素C，即使他们正在接受有副作用的治疗，对其整体健康不利。

english.passage: Medical columnist: Some doctors recommend taking vitamin C to help maintain overall health because vitamin C is an antioxidant, a substance that protects the body from certain types of oxygen particles that can trigger disease. People suffering from various ailments are encouraged to take vitamin C to guard against developing other health problems. However, doctors are now discouraging some cancer patients from taking vitamin C, even when they are undergoing therapies with side effects that are detrimental to their overall health.
english.question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to explain why the doctors' recommendation to some cancer patients differs from the general recommendation regarding vitamin C?
options: (A)Some kinds of cancer cells absorb large amounts of vitamin C, which interferes with the oxidation mechanism by which many cancer therapies kill cancer cells.
(B)Vitamin C has not been shown to reduce people's risk of developing cancer, even at the very high dosage levels recommended by some doctors.
(C)Cancer cells that are susceptible to certain types of cancer therapies are not likely to be affected by the presence of vitamin C.
(D)The better the overall health of cancer patients while undergoing therapy, the more likely they are to experience a full recovery.
(E)Certain side effects of cancer therapies that are detrimental to patients' overall health are not affected by vitamin C.
english.label: MUL
english.answer: (A)Some kinds of cancer cells absorb large amounts of vitamin C, which interferes with the oxidation mechanism by which many cancer therapies kill cancer cells.
choices: (A)Some kinds of cancer cells absorb large amounts of vitamin C, which interferes with the oxidation mechanism by which many cancer therapies kill cancer cells.
(B)Vitamin C has not been shown to reduce people's risk of developing cancer, even at the very high dosage levels recommended by some doctors.
(C)Cancer cells that are susceptible to certain types of cancer therapies are not likely to be affected by the presence of vitamin C.
(D)The better the overall health of cancer patients while undergoing therapy, the more likely they are to experience a full recovery.
(E)Certain side effects of cancer therapies that are detrimental to patients' overall health are not affected by vitamin C.
english.background: Medical columnist: Some doctors recommend taking vitamin C to help maintain overall health because vitamin C is an antioxidant, a substance that protects the body from certain types of oxygen particles that can trigger disease. People suffering from various ailments are encouraged to take vitamin C to guard against developing other health problems. However, doctors are now discouraging some cancer patients from taking vitamin C, even when they are undergoing therapies with side effects that are detrimental to their overall health.

chinese.question: 斯密的言论可以最直接地被用作以下哪种观点的论据之一？
chinese.label: MUL
choices: (A)一个民主政府不会侵犯任何公民的权利。
(B)儿童拥有的权利必须得到任何统治他们的政治当局的尊重。
(C)针对儿童的新闻节目会给他们足够的信息，使他们能够以知情的方式投票。
(D)如果剥夺儿童的投票权会导致对充分民主的任何限制，这种限制必须被接受。
(E)如果父母在政治领域不能充分代表其子女的利益，这些利益将由其他人充分代表。
chinese.background: 罗西：人们生活在一个其利益不被代表的政府之下，是不民主的。所以儿童应该有投票权，因为有时儿童的利益与父母的利益是不同的。史密斯：诚然，儿童的利益并不总是与他们父母的利益相同；他们父母那一代人的政府赤字以后会影响他们自己那一代人的生活水平。但是，即使孩子们被告知影响他们的问题（一般情况下不是这样的），他们对能做什么或应该做什么的概念也太简单了，他们的时间视野与成年人根本不同，所以我们不能让他们承担投票的责任。

english.passage: Rossi: It is undemocratic for people to live under a government in which their interests are not represented. So children should have the right to vote, since sometimes the interests of children are different from those of their parents. Smith: Granted, children's interests are not always the same as their parents'; governmental deficits incurred by their parents' generation will later affect their own generation's standard of living. But even if children are told about the issues affecting them, which is not generally the case, their conceptions of what can or should be done are too simple, and their time horizons are radically different from those of adults, so we cannot give them the responsibility of voting.
english.question: Smith's statements can most directly be used as part of an argument for which one of the following views?
options: (A)A democratic government does not infringe on the rights of any of its citizens.
(B)Children have rights that must be respected by any political authority that rules over them.
(C)News programs for children would give them enough information to enable them to vote in an informed way.
(D)If there are any limitations on full democracy that result from denying the vote to children, such limitations must be accepted.
(E)If parents do not adequately represent their children's interests in the political sphere, those interests will be adequately represented by someone else.
english.label: MUL
english.answer: (D)If there are any limitations on full democracy that result from denying the vote to children, such limitations must be accepted.
choices: (A)A democratic government does not infringe on the rights of any of its citizens.
(B)Children have rights that must be respected by any political authority that rules over them.
(C)News programs for children would give them enough information to enable them to vote in an informed way.
(D)If there are any limitations on full democracy that result from denying the vote to children, such limitations must be accepted.
(E)If parents do not adequately represent their children's interests in the political sphere, those interests will be adequately represented by someone else.
english.background: Rossi: It is undemocratic for people to live under a government in which their interests are not represented. So children should have the right to vote, since sometimes the interests of children are different from those of their parents. Smith: Granted, children's interests are not always the same as their parents'; governmental deficits incurred by their parents' generation will later affect their own generation's standard of living. But even if children are told about the issues affecting them, which is not generally the case, their conceptions of what can or should be done are too simple, and their time horizons are radically different from those of adults, so we cannot give them the responsibility of voting.

chinese.question: 以下哪一项是上述论点所要求的假设？
chinese.label: MUL
choices: (A)某品种猕猴的遗传基因的突变可以在短至几年或几十年的时间跨度内发生。
(B)在猕猴种群中出现的新的行为模式在几年或几十年的时间里不一定是遗传上预先决定的。
(C)只有当行为在一个动物种群中成为典型时，我们才能得出结论，该品种或物种的基因发生了改变。
(D)猕猴的社会行为是完全独立于它们的遗传的。
(E)猕猴的新行为模式将持续数代。
chinese.background: 1963年，人们观察到一只年轻的猕猴冒险进入一个温泉，取回掉入的食物。很快，其他猕猴也开始进入温泉，几年后，这种行为被整个猴群所采纳。在1963年之前，从来没有人在温泉中观察到猕猴；到1990年，这支队伍在冬季经常在那里度过。因此，这些猕猴能够采用并传递新的社会行为模式，而不是完全被其遗传基因所俘虏。

english.passage: In 1963, a young macaque monkey was observed venturing into a hot spring to retrieve food which had fallen in. Soon, other macaques began to enter the spring, and over a few years this behavior was adopted by the entire troop. Prior to 1963, no macaques had ever been observed in the hot spring; by 1990, the troop was regularly spending time there during the winters. Thus, these macaques are able to adopt and pass on new patterns of social behavior, and are not complete captives of their genetic heritage.
english.question: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the argument above?
options: (A)Mutations in the genetic heritage of a certain variety of macaques can occur over a time span as short as a few years or decades.
(B)New patterns of behavior that emerge in macaque populations over the course of a few years or decades are not necessarily genetically predetermined.
(C)Only when behaviors become typical among an animal population can we conclude that a genetic alteration has occurred in that variety or species.
(D)The social behaviors of macaques are completely independent of their genetic heritage.
(E)The macaques' new pattern of behavior will persist over several generations.
english.label: MUL
english.answer: (B)New patterns of behavior that emerge in macaque populations over the course of a few years or decades are not necessarily genetically predetermined.
choices: (A)Mutations in the genetic heritage of a certain variety of macaques can occur over a time span as short as a few years or decades.
(B)New patterns of behavior that emerge in macaque populations over the course of a few years or decades are not necessarily genetically predetermined.
(C)Only when behaviors become typical among an animal population can we conclude that a genetic alteration has occurred in that variety or species.
(D)The social behaviors of macaques are completely independent of their genetic heritage.
(E)The macaques' new pattern of behavior will persist over several generations.
english.background: In 1963, a young macaque monkey was observed venturing into a hot spring to retrieve food which had fallen in. Soon, other macaques began to enter the spring, and over a few years this behavior was adopted by the entire troop. Prior to 1963, no macaques had ever been observed in the hot spring; by 1990, the troop was regularly spending time there during the winters. Thus, these macaques are able to adopt and pass on new patterns of social behavior, and are not complete captives of their genetic heritage.

chinese.question: 以下哪一项是论证所依赖的假设？
chinese.label: MUL
choices: (A)垂钓者捕获湖鳟鱼的难易程度随一年中的时间和水温的变化而变化。
(B)冷水密度大，因此比相对温暖的水更重。
(C)湖鳟鱼只存在于深温带的湖泊里。
(D)湖鳟鱼在一年中的不同时期不会改变它们的进食习惯。
(E)在表面有残冰的深温带湖泊中，深冬的 "周转 "尚未发生。
chinese.background: 在深温带湖泊中，水温随深度而变化。在冬季，最冷的水在顶部；在夏季，在底部。温度分布的变化，或 "周转"，发生在秋季和冬末--通常，湖鳟鱼会在最冷的水中被发现。因此，如果垂钓者在深温带湖泊中寻找湖鳟鱼，而这些湖泊在冬末部分结冰，他们最好避开湖鳟鱼的夏季栖息地，而在浅水湾或靠近水面的岩石点钓鱼。

english.passage: In deep temperate lakes, water temperatures vary according to depth. In winter, the coldest water is at the top; in summer, at the bottom. The changes in temperature distribution,or "turnover," occur in fall and late winter- Lake trout will be found, as a rule, in the coldest water. So, if anglers seek lake trout in deep temperate lakes while these lakes are partially iced over in late winter, they will do best to eschew the lake trout's summer haunts and fish instead in a shallow bay or close to the surface off a rocky point.
english.question: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
options: (A)The ease with which lake trout can be caught by anglers varies with the time of year and the water temperature.
(B)Cold water is denser, and therefore heavier,than relatively warmer water.
(C)Lake txout are found exclusively in deep temperate lakes.
(D)Lake trout do not alter their feeding habits from one part of the year to another.
(E)In deep temperate lakes that have ice residues on the surface, late-winter "turnover" has not yet occurred.
english.label: MUL
english.answer: (E)In deep temperate lakes that have ice residues on the surface, late-winter "turnover" has not yet occurred.
choices: (A)The ease with which lake trout can be caught by anglers varies with the time of year and the water temperature.
(B)Cold water is denser, and therefore heavier,than relatively warmer water.
(C)Lake txout are found exclusively in deep temperate lakes.
(D)Lake trout do not alter their feeding habits from one part of the year to another.
(E)In deep temperate lakes that have ice residues on the surface, late-winter "turnover" has not yet occurred.
english.background: In deep temperate lakes, water temperatures vary according to depth. In winter, the coldest water is at the top; in summer, at the bottom. The changes in temperature distribution,or "turnover," occur in fall and late winter- Lake trout will be found, as a rule, in the coldest water. So, if anglers seek lake trout in deep temperate lakes while these lakes are partially iced over in late winter, they will do best to eschew the lake trout's summer haunts and fish instead in a shallow bay or close to the surface off a rocky point.

chinese.question: 在下列各项中，哪一项得到了上述信息的最有力支持？
chinese.label: MUL
choices: (A)含类黄酮高的食物在巴拿马大陆不容易得到。
(B)住在岛上的库纳人喝可可是因为他们相信可可对他们的健康有好处。
(C)库纳人有低血压的遗传倾向。
(D)住在巴拿马大陆的库纳人的血压一般比住在大陆的其他人高。
(E)每天喝几杯富含类黄酮的可可往往可以预防高血压。
chinese.background: 库纳人是原产于巴拿马几个岛屿的民族，一般来说，他们的高血压发病率很低。但是搬到巴拿马大陆的库纳人的高血压发病率并不低。住在岛上的库纳人与住在大陆的人不同，他们通常每天喝几杯可可。这种可可的加工程度很低，因此含有大量的类黄酮。

english.passage: The Kuna, a people native to several Panamanian islands, generally have a low incidence of high blood pressure. But Kuna who have moved to the Panamanian mainland do not have a low incidence of high blood pressure. Kuna who live on the islands, unlike those who live on the mainland, typically drink several cups of cocoa a day. This cocoa is minimally processed and thus high in flavonoids.
english.question: Of the following, which one is most strongly supported by the information above?
options: (A)Foods high in flavonoids are not readily available on the Panamanian mainland.
(B)Kuna who live on the islands drink cocoa because they believe that it is beneficial to their health.
(C)The Kuna have a genetic predisposition to low blood pressure.
(D)Kuna who live on the Panamanian mainland generally have higher blood pressure than other people who live on the mainland.
(E)Drinking several cups of flavonoid-rich cocoa per day tends to prevent high blood pressure.
english.label: MUL
english.answer: (E)Drinking several cups of flavonoid-rich cocoa per day tends to prevent high blood pressure.
choices: (A)Foods high in flavonoids are not readily available on the Panamanian mainland.
(B)Kuna who live on the islands drink cocoa because they believe that it is beneficial to their health.
(C)The Kuna have a genetic predisposition to low blood pressure.
(D)Kuna who live on the Panamanian mainland generally have higher blood pressure than other people who live on the mainland.
(E)Drinking several cups of flavonoid-rich cocoa per day tends to prevent high blood pressure.
english.background: The Kuna, a people native to several Panamanian islands, generally have a low incidence of high blood pressure. But Kuna who have moved to the Panamanian mainland do not have a low incidence of high blood pressure. Kuna who live on the islands, unlike those who live on the mainland, typically drink several cups of cocoa a day. This cocoa is minimally processed and thus high in flavonoids.

chinese.question: 以下哪一项如果是真的，最有助于解释上述新生婴儿的能力？
chinese.label: MUL
choices: (A)面部模式识别的某些能力在人类中是与生俱来的，而不是学习来的。
(B)婴儿盯着一个物体的时间越长，婴儿就越觉得这个物体有趣。
(C)婴儿学会将人脸与舒适和营养的必需品联系起来。
(D)婴儿盯着一个物体的时间越少，婴儿对该物体的偏爱就越弱。
(E)婴儿学会将人的声音与人脸的形象联系起来。
chinese.background: 研究人员发现，在出生后几个小时，婴儿就能从其他图像中分辨出人脸。婴儿盯着人脸的图画的时间比盯着空白的椭圆或面部特征被打乱的图画的时间长。

english.passage: Researchers have found that, hours after birth, infants are able to distinguish faces from other images. Infants stare at drawings of faces for longer periods of time than they do at blank ovals or drawings in which facial features are scrambled.
english.question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to explain the ability of newborn infants described above?
options: (A)Certain abilities of facial pattern recognition are innate in humans, rather than learned.
(B)The longer an infant stares at an object, the more interesting the infant finds that object.
(C)Infants learn to associate human faces with the necessities of comfort and nourishment.
(D)The less an infant stares at an object, the weaker the preference the infant has for that object.
(E)Infants learn to associate the sound of human voices with the images of human faces.
english.label: MUL
english.answer: (A)Certain abilities of facial pattern recognition are innate in humans, rather than learned.
choices: (A)Certain abilities of facial pattern recognition are innate in humans, rather than learned.
(B)The longer an infant stares at an object, the more interesting the infant finds that object.
(C)Infants learn to associate human faces with the necessities of comfort and nourishment.
(D)The less an infant stares at an object, the weaker the preference the infant has for that object.
(E)Infants learn to associate the sound of human voices with the images of human faces.
english.background: Researchers have found that, hours after birth, infants are able to distinguish faces from other images. Infants stare at drawings of faces for longer periods of time than they do at blank ovals or drawings in which facial features are scrambled.

chinese.question: 以下哪一项最准确地描述了科学研究不能用来反驳人格类型与其他任何现象之间的相关性这一说法在占星家的论点中所扮演的角色？
chinese.label: MUL
choices: (A)它是为一个结论提供支持的主张，而这个结论反过来又被作为论证中得出的总结论的支持。
(B)它是一个被提供支持的结论，而这个结论反过来又被提供给论证中得出的总结论的支持。
(C)它是论证中得出的总体结论。
(D)它总结了整个论证所要否定的一个立场。
(E)它提供了一个一般原则的具体例子，而整个论证的目的就是要建立这个原则。
chinese.background: 占星师：虽然有些科学家声称人们的星座和他们的性格类型之间没有关联，但这种说法在科学上是没有道理的。因为科学没有精确的标准来区分一种人格类型和另一种人格类型，所以不能用科学研究来反驳人格类型和其他任何现象之间的相关性。

english.passage: Astrologer: Although some scientists have claimed that there is no correlation between people's astrological signs and their personality types, this claim is scientifically unjustified. Since science does not have precise criteria for distinguishing one personality type from another, scientific studies cannot be used to disprove a correlation between personality type and any other phenomenon.
english.question: Which one of the following most accurately describes the role played in the astrologer's argument by the statement that scientific studies cannot be used to disprove a correlation between personality type and any other phenomenon?
options: (A)It is a claim offered as support for a conclusion that is in turn offered as support for the overall conclusion drawn in the argument.
(B)It is a conclusion for which support is offered and that in turn is offered as support for the overall conclusion drawn in the argument.
(C)It is the overall conclusion drawn in the argument.
(D)It summarizes a position that the argument as a whole is directed toward discrediting.
(E)It provides a specific instance of the general principle that the argument as a whole is directed toward establishing.
english.label: MUL
english.answer: (B)It is a conclusion for which support is offered and that in turn is offered as support for the overall conclusion drawn in the argument.
choices: (A)It is a claim offered as support for a conclusion that is in turn offered as support for the overall conclusion drawn in the argument.
(B)It is a conclusion for which support is offered and that in turn is offered as support for the overall conclusion drawn in the argument.
(C)It is the overall conclusion drawn in the argument.
(D)It summarizes a position that the argument as a whole is directed toward discrediting.
(E)It provides a specific instance of the general principle that the argument as a whole is directed toward establishing.
english.background: Astrologer: Although some scientists have claimed that there is no correlation between people's astrological signs and their personality types, this claim is scientifically unjustified. Since science does not have precise criteria for distinguishing one personality type from another, scientific studies cannot be used to disprove a correlation between personality type and any other phenomenon.

chinese.question: 从上面的陈述中可以正确推断出以下哪一项？
chinese.label: MUL
choices: (A)在今天空气污染最严重的城市，空气质量比30年前要好。
(B)没有一个城市今天的空气污染比30年前更严重。
(C)大多数反对污染的公众呼声来自于空气污染最严重的城市的人们。
(D)今天污染最严重的城市并不是30年前污染最严重的城市。
(E)公众的批评导致了30年前空气污染最严重的城市的空气质量的改善。
chinese.background: 在过去的几十年里，公众对污染的呼声带来了更严格的排放法规。30年前空气污染最严重的城市现在的空气质量大大改善。如果没有这些更严格的规定，就不会出现这种情况。

english.passage: Over the last few decades, public outcries against pollution have brought about stricter regulations of emissions. The cities that had the most polluted air 30 years ago now have greatly improved air quality. This would not have happened without these stricter regulations.
english.question: Which one of the following can be properly inferred from the statements above?
options: (A)In the city with the worst air pollution today, the air quality is better than it was 30 years ago.
(B)No city has worse air pollution today than it did 30 years ago.
(C)Most of the public outcries against pollution came from people in the cities that had the most polluted air.
(D)The most polluted cities today are not the cities that were the most polluted 30 years ago.
(E)Public criticism led to an improvement in the air quality of the cities that had the most polluted air 30 years ago.
english.label: MUL
english.answer: (E)Public criticism led to an improvement in the air quality of the cities that had the most polluted air 30 years ago.
choices: (A)In the city with the worst air pollution today, the air quality is better than it was 30 years ago.
(B)No city has worse air pollution today than it did 30 years ago.
(C)Most of the public outcries against pollution came from people in the cities that had the most polluted air.
(D)The most polluted cities today are not the cities that were the most polluted 30 years ago.
(E)Public criticism led to an improvement in the air quality of the cities that had the most polluted air 30 years ago.
english.background: Over the last few decades, public outcries against pollution have brought about stricter regulations of emissions. The cities that had the most polluted air 30 years ago now have greatly improved air quality. This would not have happened without these stricter regulations.

chinese.question: 以下哪一项是社论论点所依赖的假设？
chinese.label: MUL
choices: (A)在漫长的休息时间里，儿童有忘记他们所学知识的倾向。
(B)农民的孩子需要继续遵守由学习时间和长休息时间穿插组成的校历。
(C)校历中的长时间休息应该被不长于工人平均假期的休息所取代。
(D)改变目前的校历，缩短休息时间将有利于农业生活。
(E)由没有长时间休息的学习阶段组成的校历比有长时间休息的校历更符合儿童的利益。
chinese.background: 社论：目前校历的结构是为了满足二十世纪初农业生活的要求而建立的。在那些日子里，农民需要他们的孩子有很长的休息时间，在此期间他们可以留在家里帮助收割。因此，当代的学年是由学习期和长假穿插组成的。但是，农业生活不再占据我们大多数公民的生活，所以我们现在可以做出有利于儿童利益的改变。因此，应从校历中删除长休息时间。

english.passage: Editorial: The structure of the present school calendar was established to satisfy the requirements of early-twentieth-century agricultural life. In those days, farmers needed their children to have long breaks during which they could remain at home and help with the harvest. The contemporary school year is thus made up of periods of study interspersed with long breaks. But agricultural life no longer occupies most of our citizens, so we can now make changes that serve the interests of children. Therefore, long breaks should be removed from the school calendar.
english.question: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the editorial's argument depends?
options: (A)During long breaks children have a tendency to forget what they have learned.
(B)Children of farmers need to continue observing a school calendar made up of periods of study interspersed with long breaks.
(C)Long breaks in the school calendar should be replaced with breaks that are no longer than workers' average vacations.
(D)A change in the present school calendar that shortened breaks would serve the interests of agricultural life.
(E)A school calendar made up of periods of study without long breaks would serve the interests of children more than a school calendar with long breaks.
english.label: MUL
english.answer: (E)A school calendar made up of periods of study without long breaks would serve the interests of children more than a school calendar with long breaks.
choices: (A)During long breaks children have a tendency to forget what they have learned.
(B)Children of farmers need to continue observing a school calendar made up of periods of study interspersed with long breaks.
(C)Long breaks in the school calendar should be replaced with breaks that are no longer than workers' average vacations.
(D)A change in the present school calendar that shortened breaks would serve the interests of agricultural life.
(E)A school calendar made up of periods of study without long breaks would serve the interests of children more than a school calendar with long breaks.
english.background: Editorial: The structure of the present school calendar was established to satisfy the requirements of early-twentieth-century agricultural life. In those days, farmers needed their children to have long breaks during which they could remain at home and help with the harvest. The contemporary school year is thus made up of periods of study interspersed with long breaks. But agricultural life no longer occupies most of our citizens, so we can now make changes that serve the interests of children. Therefore, long breaks should be removed from the school calendar.

chinese.question: 以下哪项，如果是真的，可以为论证的结论提供最大的支持？
chinese.label: MUL
choices: (A)木鼠用死的、脆的树枝筑巢，而不是用活的。
(B)许多不同的动物使用毒橡树和毒藤作为食物来源。
(C)植物通过产生化学物质来保护自己是很常见的。
(D)在大约85%的人口中，非常少量的尿素可以引起皮疹。
(E)在人类改变了自然森林生态系统的地方，毒橡树和毒藤生长得特别好。
chinese.background: 尽管一些动物对尿素（一种由毒橡树和毒常春藤等植物产生的油）表现出轻微的皮肤反应，但似乎只有人类因接触它而产生痛苦的皮疹。事实上，木鼠甚至用毒橡树植物的树枝来筑巢。因此，尿素可能不是作为一种化学防御手段在这些植物中进化出来的。

english.passage: Although some animals exhibit a mild skin reaction to urushiol, an oil produced by plants such as poison oak and poison ivy, it appears that only humans develop painful rashes from touching it. In fact, wood rats even use branches from the poison oak plant to build their nests. Therefore, urushiol probably did not evolve in these plants as a chemical defense.
english.question: Which one of the following, if true, adds the most support for the conclusion of the argument?
options: (A)Wood rats build their nests using dead, brittle branches, not live ones.
(B)A number of different animals use poison oakand poison ivy as food sources.
(C)It is common for plants to defend themselves by producing chemical substances.
(D)In approximately 85 percent of the human population, very small amounts of urushiol can cause a rash.
(E)Poison oak and poison ivy grow particularly well in places where humans have altered natural forest ecosystems.
english.label: MUL
english.answer: (B)A number of different animals use poison oakand poison ivy as food sources.
choices: (A)Wood rats build their nests using dead, brittle branches, not live ones.
(B)A number of different animals use poison oakand poison ivy as food sources.
(C)It is common for plants to defend themselves by producing chemical substances.
(D)In approximately 85 percent of the human population, very small amounts of urushiol can cause a rash.
(E)Poison oak and poison ivy grow particularly well in places where humans have altered natural forest ecosystems.
english.background: Although some animals exhibit a mild skin reaction to urushiol, an oil produced by plants such as poison oak and poison ivy, it appears that only humans develop painful rashes from touching it. In fact, wood rats even use branches from the poison oak plant to build their nests. Therefore, urushiol probably did not evolve in these plants as a chemical defense.

chinese.question: 以下哪条原则如果有效，最有助于证明法官的推理？
chinese.label: MUL
choices: (A)地方法规和国家法规不能相互重叠。
(B)地方法规可以比国家法规更不严格，但不能更严格。
(C)国家法规要求的任何行为也是地方法规要求的。
(D)不知道两部法规之间的区别并不是不遵守法规的充分借口。
(E)符合一项法律的行为不一定符合另一项法律的规定。
chinese.background: 法官：被告承认不遵守国家建筑法规，但要求不对其进行处罚，因为他对国家或地方建筑法规是否适用于他所建造的地区感到困惑。如果他被指控不遵守地方法规，这个借口可能是可以接受的，但由于他被指控不遵守国家法规，他的借口是不可接受的。

english.passage: Judge: The defendant admits noncompliance with national building codes but asks that penalties not be imposed because he was confused as to whether national or local building codes applied to the area in which he was building. This excuse might be acceptable had he been charged with noncompliance with local codes, but since he is charged with noncompliance with national codes, his excuse is unacceptable.
english.question: Which one of the following principles, if valid, most helps to justify the judge's reasoning?
options: (A)Local codes and national codes must not overlap with each other.
(B)Local codes may be less strict, but not more strict, than national codes.
(C)Any behavior required by national codes is also required by local codes.
(D)Ignorance of the difference between two codes is not an adequate excuse for noncompliance.
(E)A behavior that is in compliance with one law is not necessarily in compliance with another.
english.label: MUL
english.answer: (C)Any behavior required by national codes is also required by local codes.
choices: (A)Local codes and national codes must not overlap with each other.
(B)Local codes may be less strict, but not more strict, than national codes.
(C)Any behavior required by national codes is also required by local codes.
(D)Ignorance of the difference between two codes is not an adequate excuse for noncompliance.
(E)A behavior that is in compliance with one law is not necessarily in compliance with another.
english.background: Judge: The defendant admits noncompliance with national building codes but asks that penalties not be imposed because he was confused as to whether national or local building codes applied to the area in which he was building. This excuse might be acceptable had he been charged with noncompliance with local codes, but since he is charged with noncompliance with national codes, his excuse is unacceptable.

chinese.question: 如果上面的陈述是真的，那么以下哪一项也一定是真的？
chinese.label: MUL
choices: (A)豹子目前的栖息地的某些部分只是质量不高。
(B)如果佛罗里达豹的数量有一天超过了250只，它将是自我维持的。
(C)除非佛罗里达豹获得一个更大的栖息地，否则他们的人口将不能自我维持。
(D)佛罗里达豹的数量将永远不会超过其目前的水平。
(E)今天，佛罗里达豹所占据的栖息地比它们在20世纪70年代的时候要大。
chinese.background: 今天有70至100只佛罗里达豹活着。这代表他们的数量比20世纪70年代有了非常大的增长，但他们的人口必须达到至少250人，才能自我维持。然而，它们目前的栖息地不足以支持更多的这些动物。

english.passage: There are 70 to 100 Florida panthers alive today. This represents a very large increase over their numbers in the 1970s, but their population must reach at least 250 if it is to be self-sustaining. Their current habitat is not large enough to support any more of these animals, however.
english.question: If the statements above are true, which one of the following must also be true?
options: (A)Some part of the panthers' current habitat is only of marginal quality.
(B)If the population of Florida panthers ever exceeds 250, it will be self-sustaining.
(C)Unless Florida panthers acquire a larger habitat, their population will not be self-sustaining.
(D)The population of Florida panthers will never increase much beyond its current level.
(E)Today, Florida panthers occupy a larger habitat than they did in the 1970s.
english.label: MUL
english.answer: (C)Unless Florida panthers acquire a larger habitat, their population will not be self-sustaining.
choices: (A)Some part of the panthers' current habitat is only of marginal quality.
(B)If the population of Florida panthers ever exceeds 250, it will be self-sustaining.
(C)Unless Florida panthers acquire a larger habitat, their population will not be self-sustaining.
(D)The population of Florida panthers will never increase much beyond its current level.
(E)Today, Florida panthers occupy a larger habitat than they did in the 1970s.
english.background: There are 70 to 100 Florida panthers alive today. This represents a very large increase over their numbers in the 1970s, but their population must reach at least 250 if it is to be self-sustaining. Their current habitat is not large enough to support any more of these animals, however.
